Hi Michael

>> Personally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather m=
ake
evrything
public and testable and expose real APIs via Java Interfaces.=


I don't understand what exactly you mean by this, please elaborate or
cou=
ld you lead me to a place where I can see some examples of the above.

Than=
ks
Chirag

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msi=
lverstein@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, October 15, 2003 11:07 PM
To: j=
unit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, =
its urgent



> -----Original Message-----
> From: Dave Astels [mailto:dave=
@...] 
> Private methods support public methods.  Therefore well tes=
ted public 
> methods will include the behaviour of the private methods.  
=
> 
> There is no real reason for directly testing private methods.
> 

Doma=
in objects support the GUI. By the logic above a well tested GUI
will inclu=
de the behavior of the domain objects, so there is no reason
to unit test t=
he domain objects :-)

I've occasionally found reason to write unit tests f=
or private,
supporting methods. Often you loose efficiency testing supporti=
ng
methods indirectly via their caller - such as in the case where you want=

to test their ability to properly handle a range of input values. 

Person=
ally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather make
everything public=
 and testable and expose real APIs via Java Interfaces.

To answer the orig=
inal poster: google junit + "private methods"
